body:
cc @pluskid @hetong007 

Softmax continue to function correctly, exception with a message to switch to SoftmaxOutput
I think this is a other way of model parallel

everything was included but I was using an old version of CUDA (4.4) . after upgrade to 7.5 the issue seems to be gone !
I could compile and reinstall.
Thanks a lot

Can you give a it more detail on what kind of triplet information you would like to have.
-  Say get multiple mini-batch of data,  run a scoring over current network, and generate the pairs training set?

It is possible, in a sense that all the things after data loading goes into python side, and you can always insert such augmentation step (pairing) on python side to generate the triplets. It requires  a bit tweaking on current code.
#444  #450 Imposes the changes for python and R
@hjk41  can you make a windows build for the most recent version?

Precisely, I generate the batch of triplets as follow : 
- start with parent dataset that contains labeled images ( image + class )
- at each step 
  - create a batch with an evenly distributed images per class ( say n classes with m images each)
  - from this mini batch, Create a batch of triplets formed with an anchor image, positive image and negative image. The negative images are selected wrt to current network score. 
  - update parameters using this batch of triplets.
    with fuel, all of this is done by chaining different data transformer. The SGD optimizer just fetches the batch from the pipeline. Do we have similar feature with Mxnet ?
The data transforming pipeline on the IO side was not as rich as you mentioned. However, the pipline you mentioned should be able to implemented using the current python API
Updated in #443

How should I get started for that : 
- customizing the data iterator ?
- changing the model.fit method ?
Starting from the getting data part of model.fit should be the easiest way. Customizing data iterator with a pipeline should make the approach more modularized and suitable for future usecases
I made a fix: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/452

I recompiled Rcpp and it worked.
May be related to Ubuntu update.
Or may be not...

Thanks @pommedeterresautee !  I have added you to the https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/CONTRIBUTORS.md 

Can you also make a example here https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/R-package/vignettes  ?

Some comment:
- Please change sudo back to `false`
  - Let us only do osx build on R
- Consider upgrade the roxygen to 5.0.0, so the roxygen message won't be duplicated and we won't touch so many Rd files.
- Please do a squash of the recent commits so the updates on Rd files don't need to be touch
@tqchen Fixed according to your comments. Sorry about the roxygen thing. I am using my old mac and I forgot to update it.
You want to uncomment the r_task grid to open the build.
Yes but I still need to fix the error during final installation step. I will work on it later along with other more robust test cases in a separate PR.
OK, this is merged. cc @thirdwing
related to #457
Oh should've seen this issue earlier. Yes there must be a `sudo` during linux build. Is it that if we enable `sudo` then some other builds could fail?

If sudo is disabled, then travis uses [container based build](http://docs.travis-ci.com/user/workers/container-based-infrastructure/), which caches the data and make things faster.

Unfortunately we cannot partially enable sudo, and I guess OSX test should be sufficient for most cases(usually OSX is the place to fail easier)
Got it. Yeah let's stick with just OSX for now.
@thirdwing Let us only support saving list of ndarray for now, and report error for single ndarray. As discussed with @hetong007
You can just wrap the single one in a list: https://github.com/thirdwing/mxnet/blob/master/R-package/R/ndarray.R#L36
Users might be confused if they saved an ndarray but got a list after loaded back.

As user will get confused by getting a list after loading back, so we can disable it for now. 

Special treatment might could be done to encode a special list, say the first element is a 1x1 ndarray with key="**ndarray_workspace**", then the behavior indicates load ndarray back

- I think we can point GPU user to advanced build for now
- Alternatively, allow separate build of libmxnet and R package as in Julia
  - c.f. https://github.com/dmlc/MXNet.jl/blob/master/deps/build.jl
  - The build can detect the existence of mxnet library, via MXNET_HOME env variable
  - If not exist, it will try to build a cpu only version.
In terms of windows, I think some of us have windows machine, so @thirdwing if you can create an instruction(better script) to pack the things, some of us could help building that
You can use it. The only thing to change is replace onehot input to your feature vector.

(1) For windows, CPU version can be built using GCC toolchain and I didn't see any problems;

(2) For Mac and Linux, the building is quite easy: `make all && R CMD INSTALL R-package`

I don't see onehot input in  char_lstm.ipynb. Can you tell me which part of the code has onehot encoding?

My input data is sequence of float numbers and like to use LSTM to predict output, x(n+1) when input is x(n).

Thanks,

Yes, I think this is the way to go, expose the image index into the python side, that was what image index was originally designed for. This would involve a bit addition to the C API as index is best exposed as numpy integer array without being lazily stored.

Are you interested in contribution?
cc @sneakerkg
Can you be a bit specific? The major reason is that there are two files in the model(symbol json and parameters) and the current API is designed to save them in consistent way.

Please submit a PR for this, this was due to some choices in the parameters side. You should be able to locate the num_args in the operators you performed. Instead of  using `DECLARE_PARAMETER(num_args).set_range(1,100)` change it to `DECLARE_PARAMETER(num_args).set_lower_bound(1)`
cc @antinucleon
all sides updated
Thx ! Given that we can set this using that command, what you suggest the PR is for ?
Oh, this is the code on C++ side, not python. for example https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/concat-inl.h#L31
This being said, I do not know in which specific operator this num_args constraint sits, so will need a bit of your help in catching it:)
Can we treat it as a global environment variable ?
The idea is by default we should have no limit in num_args. The previous settings are quite arbitrary and should be corrected
I prefer the first one. Example should be the first code piece that helps a user to learn the way to call the function. So the more convenience the better.

Do you think the same dataset than XGBoost is Ok? (the one with mushroom)
If yes should be easy to copy paste and we are sure it works...
Moreover, it would make it possible to compare results from both packages.
BTW, in the current building process, all examples are not tested

@tqchen do we support sparse matrix input, or we need to do sparse -> dense conversion first? 
For the latter case, I now prefer to use two data sets to represent regression and classification respectively. They could be the `Sonar` and `BostonHousing` as in the document or other "easier" data sets.

Yes, pls go ahead to do so

You might want to merge in my PR here:https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/456
@piiswrong Yes, please merge that PR and I will rebase later.

If I have correctly understood, with the current implementation of `mx.model.save`, there is no way to provide a folder path. Therefore the model and the parameters are saved in the working directory.

Moreover, I feel it is unusual to force the way the file name is built. May be the user have a specific idea of what he wants.

In both cases, I feel the API is slightly unnatural for no obvious reasons.

@pommedeterresautee We can provide an optional parameter for the folder path.

I think it is still better to let symbol and parameter files have the same prefix.
It does not have to be in current path, the prefix can be path to say model folder plus the file name
ok, I will try it~

Softmax (recently renamed to SoftmaxOutput) is a loss layer. It's not intended to be used as internal layers. There was a discussion on this: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/426

However there is an easy patch for your need you can do. Cudnn provide softmax implementation for internal layers. You can modify the cudnn_activation-inl.h file under src/operator and add a new activation with cudnn API.

If you figured out a solution, your are welcome to contribute to mxnet by submitting PR.

Hi, 

Thanks a lot for your help and the example you showed is detailed and helpful in some ways. And I am "almost" finish the python implementation. Basically:
1. configure neural nets
2. bind those symbols to an executor
3. self defined iteration and EM update
   (3.1) E  step: executor.forward and combine some functions, then sampling
   (3.2) M step: executor.backward and combine some functions, then updating

Are these steps right? However, current python implementation is not efficient enough, considering the python sampler. So my advisor suggested to the cpp implementation, and the sampler could use the "dmlc/experimental-lda" (need many changes). So I was wondering if you have cpp examples? I saw the example folder and did not see any cpp examples

I was delayed by something else in the past weeks, and would try to catch up the progress in the coming weeks, so please do not close this talk recently.

Thanks  a lot for your help

The current state-of-the-art on the [VOC 2012 segmentation competition leaderboard](http://host.robots.ox.ac.uk:8080/leaderboard/displaylb.php?challengeid=11&compid=6) is deep parsing network [1]. Not implemented operations include padded convolution filter copy initialization, up-sampling, local convolution and channels block min pooling.

[1] Ziwei Liu, Xiaoxiao Li, Ping Luo, Chen Change Loy, and Xiaoou Tang. Semantic Image Segmentation via Deep Parsing Network. ICCV 2015.

Currently the example doesn't support multi-GPU. We hope to settle down a general RNN model soon, which will handle multi-GPU easily like FeedForward models. 

Currently there is no caption example, but I don't think it is far from it :

I also think it is not obvious that prefix may be used for that purpose too.

There are two possibilities:
- improving documentation
- adding a new parameter

I would prefer the second option.
@thirdwing @hetong007 @tqchen Let me know what you prefer.

@antinucleon I think it might be possible to use the built-in `FeedForward` to train the LSTM example once #468 is merged, by providing a customized data iter that produce inputs from text (and also initial zero states for sequence beginning). Because we explicitly unroll the network and use a fixed sequence length. It looks exactly like a simple feed forward network. But for more general case, we still need to build explicit RNN interface.
See #436
@pluskid can we do the same thing from Julia?
Not yet, but that is the next thing to add. Should be fairly straightforward. Hopefully I could find some time to add that this week. But you are also very welcome to contribute if interested in.

I will see if I find time this week to do that.

Do we have the equivalent of `theano.tensor.grad` here, or do we always have to implement the backward function ?
Do we need to differentiate between data and label?

The only difference is that during training data and label is copied into the network. But during prediction only data is copied. During evaluating on the validation set, data and label are copied into different places. I also found it a bit redundant but I did not have a better way to handle this in more general case.

So the icc/icpc version is:

```
icpc -v
icpc version 15.0.3 (gcc version 4.9.2 compatibility)
```

The gcc version I used for compiling mxnet is:

```
g++ --version
g++ (GCC) 4.9.2
```

It depends on the level of customization. The NumpyOp so far provides the `atomic` operators, in a sense that it can be used to compose together with other operators. So we will need a way to know its gradient. 

However, if you define operators such as exp, and relu. And you compose them together using

```
out = relu(exp(in))
```

You do not need to define the backward function of this composition.

Please update the newest version of mxnet, there is not bug for this example here, the output is like this:

``` r
[wuwei@localhost mxnet]$ python example/mnist/mlp_numpy.py
INFO:root:Start training with [cpu(0)]
```

I found that the swapaxis supports template only, that means I need to enumerate all possible groups of swapaxis functions.for example:
swap 0 and 1, then swapaxis<1, 0>(....)
swap 0 and 2, then swapaxis<2, 0>(....)
swap 0 and 3, then swapaxis<3, 0>(....)
swap 2 and 3, then swapaxis<3, 2>(....)
........

Thanks for point it out. Yes. These could be reduced to two possible cases by use it with together reshape. For example, say X is 3 dimension (c, t, h, w), what and we want to swap c and w, what we can do is 

Swap that involves the lowest dimension

``` c++
reshape(swapaxis<0, 2>(reshape(X, (c, t *h, w))), (w, t, h, w))
```

General swap dim1, dim2

``` c++
swapaxis<1, 3>(reshape(X, (prod(shape[0:dim1]), dim1, prod(shape[dim1:dim2]), dim2, prod(dim2:end]))
```

So you can use get_with_shape function in TBlob, which allows you to convert any TBlob contiguously into 4D Tensor using above rule,m and do swap axis on 1 and 3
You may need a callback at the end of each epoch like: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/imagenet/inception-full.py#L101
Thanks to @Kublai-Jing fixed by #469

This should be able to be implemented by elementwise-scalar symbol as in the ndarray ops. The idea is to implement a ScalarOp that takes a scalar and symbol. It should be straight forward to implement this like https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/activation-inl.h

Then we can do operator overloading on python side to support the elementwise ops with scalars.
Please let us know if you are interested in take a stab.

I try it with numpy of python and it works, this is really a tricky one.
Thank you very much.
This is discussed to be added as SoftmaxTransform Operator. cc @antinucleon  Please let us know if you are interested in contributing

it seems that your *.params file and *-symbol.json file is inconsistent(the arg name : fullyconnected1_bias).
list the args of symbol by list_arguments(), and list the dict of *.params to see the key, then check that

model = mx.model.FeedForward(
        ctx = dev, symbol =mx.symbol.load('lenet_2GPU-symbol.json'), num_epoch = 10, begin_epoch=5,
        learning_rate = 0.05, momentum = 0.9, wd = 0.00001,arg_params=mx.nd.load('lenet_2GPU-0005.params'))

then I call fit.
it doesn't work now..

the name in self.arg_dict has no prefix,it comes from the symbol file 
but the name in arg_params has a prefix,it comes from arg_params file.

https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/model.py#L418
but if I remove the arg: here.
when I reload the model,it can only continue to train 1 epoch ,then an error of save_dict.update occurs.
@fhowen  i just run a test, but no that bug here, so can u paste your code?
ok.

lenet.py

from data import mnist_iterator
import mxnet as mx
import logging

data = mx.symbol.Variable('data')
#data
train, val = mnist_iterator(batch_size=300, input_shape=(1,28,28))

logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG)
dev = [mx.gpu(i) for i in range(2)]
#dev = mx.gpu()
prefix="lenet_2GPU"

model = mx.model.FeedForward(ctx = dev, symbol =mx.symbol.load('lenet_2GPU-symbol.json'), num_epoch = 10, begin_epoch=5,learning_rate = 0.05, momentum = 0.9, wd=0.00001,arg_params=mx.nd.load('lenet_2GPU-0005.params'))
#model=mx.model.load_checkpoint("lenet_2GPU",5)
model.fit(X=train, eval_data=val,
          batch_end_callback=mx.callback.Speedometer(300),
          epoch_end_callback=mx.callback.do_checkpoint(prefix))
